Last night in class, we discussed that week’s assigned reading, *Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World*, by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” In the opening chapter, Casey argues that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the organizing force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. I entered volume and pricing on the following 2 deals in Sitara: Deal 418015 CNG citygate with Tenn Prod plus transport pricing. It puts the ball in the net or it gets the hose again. Absolutely amazing—I have nothing negative to say about this game as it's exceeded my expectations and will probably exceed yours too. Fluid movement, bug/crash-free, plenty of story/content to keep you engaged, options for each and every day such as multiple practices, events (sponsorships), and even games. This review is purely based on playing MyCareer, and so far it's 10/10. Facescan worked really well for me (used it twice, first one gave me a Down syndrome forehead though..). Keep in mind, using the MyNBA2K17 app will let you facescan for free and earn daily VC. #sellout

Magic fans beware... Wizards is afraid to create a decent digital game. At its core, Magic: The Gathering is a social game. A game to enjoy with your friends (or frenemies) laughing, talking smack, and dropping game-winning bombs. Wizards of the Coast seems to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends, you can't earn gold, and gold is essential. Gold is so important that they have implemented a daily cap, understandable since gold unlocks everything in-game. But prepare for a long and tedious 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, whom you can't even speak to. If you choose to play for free, it will take you roughly 4 hours a day for upwards of a month, alone, to unlock the cards.

Being the 3rd installment in the trilogy, I'll get the bad stuff out of the way first. I quite hate prequels as they technically go backwards in a story rather than forwards (this is an issue for every prequel). Granted, it offers more storywise. The combat feels sloppy and isn't as sharp as Arkham City managed to make it. As of writing this recommendation (26/10/2013), there is a game-breaking bug that prevents a side mission from ever being completed (main story unaffected). Some gadgets are placed at a ridiculous hotkey that forces your hand to travel across the whole keyboard to reach it. It might sound minor, but during combat it could potentially break your combo.

They effectively improved Shadow Warrior (2013). The bossfights are awesome, weapons feel very nice (maybe not as good as D44M's, but still solid), enemies aren't too spongy (if you're not too careless with handling elemental and upgrade mechanics). The upgrade system is well-balanced and once you understand it, it's not too tedious. The elemental aspects and limited ammo gently encourage you to use different weapons. Lots of cool unique (being the key word here while comparing SW2 to Borderlands' formula of 'RNG' weapons) weapons that remain viable through most of the game. The music is great, especially the main theme and of course Stan Bush's tracks.

So many things were made wrong. I even don't know how to start this review. This all is related to my career. My player is an outside scorer, pg, 1.71m, has maxed stats and already has all necessary perks. Ok, and now tell me, why does the shooting skill depend on a person's height? Why can't a person who is 1.74m become as good at shooting as someone who is 1.71m? I'm 1.87m in real life, made my first player with this height and noticed then I cannot reach a higher skill than 89. Why? That's pure discrimination! And why doesn't the game tell me that before I create a character and not even when I reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!?

I think this assassin's creed nailed the mechanics on all fronts (ship battles, sailing, hunting (fish), parkour, etc). I felt much more connected to this character as well. The story starts out extremely rough but improves significantly as you play (i think this is true for every ac game personally). Edward was quite the interesting character and so were all the side characters. I felt like all the collectibles actually meant something in this ac game, which I never got from any of the previous ones. Maybe it's because I felt like they had a greater purpose in the game. They definitely were not required but they were fun to get and you got rewarded in a very balanced way.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is decent, so long as you have the money to purchase gun parts, which would be my main complaint with this game: it's pay-to-win. If I could get past that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and HRV is a great idea. I'd take this game over any Call of Duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransaction format is off-putting for me. If you're fine with this model, then by all means, have fun. But if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, just let this one pass; it's not our cup of tea.

While not perfect, this game has been highly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death leads to some frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and I lost my main character around hour 10 of 20ish. Would have really appreciated a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a 3rd party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. Plus the aiming reticle is on the small side and zoom is underpowered. With all that said, it's been a blast. I'm not typically a zombie fan, but the combination of strategy, missions, first-person shooter/beat 'em up is fantastic. I've been playing it as often as I can get away... Just one more mission, just one more supply run—or I'm running away and want to get safe before shutting the game down.

An absolutely great strategy game! Having played every single other wargame (European Escalation, and ALB), I have to say this one fits well. The number of units is great. Not sure exactly how many units there are, but there's a ton!!! Graphics are just beautiful, sounds are great, and the gameplay overall is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is very entertaining as well, no I am not kidding. However, if anyone thinks this game is 'easy', or if you are new to the strategy genre, it could take you quite some time to get it nailed down. Do not get upset, you will lose a lot of units. Just make sure you plan ahead, always have anti-air, and anti-tank.

I was negatively biased towards this game before I played it. Wasn't even sure about buying it. I dunno, the whole portal gun and portals thing seemed odd to me even though I like science fiction. Boy was I wrong. The jokes and voice acting in this game are phenomenal. Just amazing. It's not cheesy (ok it's sometimes cheesy). And each story character has their own sense of humour. Those different characters truly have distinct personalities. And the level design; it's just rad. Btw I never played the first Portal game. One of these days, I'm planning to if I can spare the time. I would never have played it if I hadn't tried the sequel.

Ok let's start with the pros(+) and cons(-) then my thoughts on this game. +some of the best characters +good story +lots of content +customizable character (you can be male or female whatever you like) +you can have a relationship with most of your companions(yes fangirls you can have a love interest) -bad graphics (I don't think graphics really matter anyway) -weird and awkward love scenes -invisible walls -there's one mission in my opinion was boring but everyone has different tastes -+ um this isn't really bad or good but for those who care your protagonist you made can't talk okay now for my thoughts. I love this game. This game is probably one of the best RPGs or games in general I have ever played. So if you're an RPG fan you probably already have this game.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the UK) watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallet just for the five-minute *Transformers* cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back, and instantly recognizable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is there. Graphically, the cel-shaded presentation is flawless, and very, very Generation One. But aside from that, it's actually a highly enjoyable game. The combat mechanics are exceptionally well done. Transforming mid-fight is often essential, and woven seamlessly into combos, making it quite unlike High Moon's outstanding *War for/Fall of Cybertron* games. Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, but some enemies (e.g. Seekers) require switching to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played it for a while, and it was nothing special. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing the game. There is a bug where it says there was an update to the terms of service, and whenever you click 'accept,' it just pops up again. You have to restart the client for it to work. Now that isn't too bad, but why do I need to link my Steam and Gface accounts? They say it's for DLC, but why is that even necessary? It's also irreversible, so now I know a company I don't care about has access to my Steam information. The game itself is mediocre. It's easily recognizable as a COD clone, except somehow they made the gunplay worse... How is that even possible?

4K at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and includes Neptune gear. What's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo Excellent port and a great entry point if you're new to the series. Just keep in mind there is lots of (skippable) talking. As usual, I'd suggest using a gamepad, but personally I had no problems with a keyboard/mouse setup, both completely rebindable. Price is about right and I wouldn't have been unhappy with the purchase. More than half the DLC is included free, which is still plenty to play with. Recommended game for all JRPG/anime/visual novel fans, provided you don't mind long breaks between the action. Cheers. No commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I experienced no performance issues even at launch, and after all these patches it plays really well. Imo, this is a truly great and fun game, although the format may be somewhat annoying (where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies every time you progress the story). I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments (where you can play as Batman + 1 more), and the ability to use the controller for most parts of the game but the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat sections was greatly appreciated. Driving your batmobile around the free-roam city, including when chasing the apc commanders, is actually quite fun once you figure out how to use the brakes to skid around corners (and when you master that, driving around the city is really quite enjoyable!)

Damn fine aaa fps shooter - that's the bottom line. It looks, sounds, and plays great - excellent fps mechanics, a compelling story, cool characters, flawless voice acting, and a badass soundtrack. Not for the faint-hearted though - some of those cutscenes were pretty darn brutal and vivid. But when a game is this good overall, it's easier to spot the flaws, and here they are as I saw 'em: - no SLI support - wtf? I had to shelve the game until I upgraded my card, as it ran too poorly on my old dual GPU GTX 590. Make sure you have a fairly decent single GPU card. - annoyingly small obstacles are often unclimbable.

English is not my native language. I am Dutch. So please overlook any typing or grammatical mistakes in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into a few categories: - graphics - controls - sound - gameplay - replayability - graphics: the game has been set in a comic-like style. The visuals are very sleek: no unnecessary details. Nice color schemes. It totally works for this game. The graphics can be set on 'high' without straining your system. I run this game on an i5 Pentium processor, with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M card - 8GB memory and it runs smoothly (Windows 8.1). - controls: the game can be played with a keyboard and mouse, but also with an Xbox controller.

You can see by the hours I put into this game that I enjoy it. This is everything I wished a search game from COD would be. But don’t buy this game thinking it’s like COD, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It’s a game in its own class and should be treated as such. Can’t tell you how many times I hear new players whine and complain about getting killed really fast. Oh god forbid you get shot in the face and actually die. It's not like that doesn’t happen in real life or anything. Edit: Okay, so I’ve been playing this game for a while now. Thrown all kinds of money at it. One of the best MP games around. A good thing to play when you’re not feeling CS:GO.

I'm 2 hours in and am dying from this game. So hilarious. Gameplay is also solid, art design is stunning, music is surprisingly high quality and fitting, the story/world has me intrigued, and the puzzles are enjoyable. But the best thing about this game beyond all that is the comedy. If you've played any RPG since the dawn of video game RPGs you will laugh at the various jokes, parodies, and references; if you've never played an RPG before then you should still appreciate the game for its humor. If you played Final Fantasy 7 or X you absolutely need to play this game, without giving too much away... I had to actually stop playing after 2 hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far.

I'm really sorry, I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I really didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded perfect for me, but the execution did nothing for me. I love puzzle and exploration games, yet I found this game completely unintuitive, and even after looking up how to progress, I still simply didn't find the gameplay fun. It also lacks a pause button entirely, or if it does have one, I never found it. Considering that many sequences in the game are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. I also feel like this game has more cutscenes than gameplay, and I end up just sitting around drumming my fingers a lot.

This game.... Phew where to even start. It was absolutely beautiful, from story to graphics I was hooked. The story wasn’t just some tale but actually felt like I was that person, trying to figure out what came next in the journey my character was telling. Gameplay was great and I learned a lot about myself through this game (mainly my fear of heights which I never had a problem with until the ice caverns). My gut churned the whole time, but I pushed through for Uncle Fred! If you guys made a DLC or second game, I would be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to everyone who was involved in making this, you created a truly beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game in which you build your civilization toward a specific goal or 'victory'. In previous games, you progressed through Earth's timeline, advancing through periods like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and the Modern Age; however, in this game, you are set in the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I enjoy about this game is that 2K took a fresh approach and introduced new mechanics such as the affinity system and orbital layer. What I didn’t enjoy was that with these new mechanics, the game could be overwhelming at times. What I think could be improved in this game is that they could incorporate some new artwork, such as the environment you experience when communicating with another leader.

Great game! Tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival game! Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. Edit: After playing 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more ''realistic'' zombie games. It's very much designed like a survival horror as you must conserve your ammo, heal your own wounds when you bleed out, take pills when you're infected, etc. Also, I find the zombies to feel very natural and well animated for a free-to-play game. P.S.: I would recommend getting 1 or 2 friends to play with, but the community is super friendly and you can usually make friends/talk with people in the chat or over voice comms.

02/07/2014 - It's a shame I can't fully recommend/enjoy this game because from the short time I've played it, I know I'd be addicted if it didn't have the following 2 game breakers. No Aussie servers - one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage and creates unbearable lag. Mind you, I played through the offline training mode and it was stuttering/lagging as well (how does that even happen?). Combine that with the poor ping, and it just ruins the game. Everything artifacts like crazy - the menus, backgrounds, training and in-game. I've never had this happen before with this card and thought it might not like my OC. Set my GPU back to stock and sure enough, it didn't make a difference.

Very late last night I finished this. The story is not particularly deep or interesting, but what makes it stand out is the storytelling. The atmosphere is filled to the brim, and the many collectibles do a great job at fleshing it out. I did learn a lot about the world of Batman, so it was a little disappointing that so few bosses were in the game. Oh well, there are enough future games to rectify that. The combat is the right amount of challenging but leans more on the easy side. Leveling up Batman wasn't very satisfying. It's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign that add nice new gameplay mechanics. Gaining access to previously unreachable areas creates a nice sense of progression.

'To the Moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Think Telltale's *The Walking Dead* is sad? Hohoho! Well, it's no match for *To the Moon*! Never before have I been so moved yet fulfilled by something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I did not care one bit. Plus, the humor of the game is great as well and it never intrudes upon the distinguished nature of the story... And the *Doctor Who* references are endless.

Bastion is a bloody brilliant game, with a truly great storyline. Set after a calamity occurs, you begin to rebuild on the bastion. There's quite a lot of choice in the game, with the option of what to build to give you an advantage, what weapons to use and what upgrades to apply to those weapons as well as what drinks to consume for bonus effects. The art style and music in the game are fantastic, everything looks so vibrant at times—who says the apocalypse has to be dull? Best of all, the game features narration based on your actions. So if you pick up a weapon then swap it for another in the armoury, the narration would mention you taking along the new weapon.

I had originally bought this game in early development, when the only currency was spacebux, and there was no 'tech tree'. This was when the game was great. All of the guns at this point were equally overpowered, so there was no issue with imbalance; everyone could kill everyone at any time. Also, the game used to provide unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You would think that for a game with 'bajillions of guns', they would at least give you more than 6 weapon slots and 3 loadouts before you have to pay to unlock more. At one point, I had about 3 pages worth of guns, and was planning new ideas for more, because personally, that's where I found the fun.

This game was a surprising gem. One often sees rave reviews of certain products that are frequently misleading. In this case, the reviews reflect the fun of this neat little game. It is an odd mix between a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, and executes it with style. I found myself enjoying characters that I wouldn’t like in other MOBA games. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a try anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up testing more as they were unlocked from playing matches. The art style and interface are oddly charming. As such, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from designing a card set for the game.

I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has had that effect on me. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are perfect. I look forward to every combat, and they've optimized combat extremely well. I had my doubts about the naval combat system, but it is so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets at a time! The only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat looks overwhelming just get out of there, regroup, and counter-attack. Thanks, devs, for an awesome experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about many changes for the series, particularly for the series’ protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original games may be upset at the changes to their beloved character, it’s certainly for the better; and this new title by Ninja Theory proves it. DmC serves as the perfect entry point for newcomers to jump into the series. It shows the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to follow. The story follows Dante as he’s thrust into the corrupt world he willfully chose to ignore.

Where do I start with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is utterly charming. It has so much detail put into it, and it is a bundle of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. It is serious when it needs to be, but isn’t a stranger to humor. The character design is on point, with various personalities and hidden depths. It stands out from other RPGs because you don’t have to kill anyone, a rare concept in the genre. With inspiration from EarthBound, one of the best RPGs I’ve played, you can tell it’s going to be great. It easily has the best soundtrack I’ve heard in years.

I am recommending this solely because it's free, and might be a more 'enjoyable' experience for others. As for my experience, the 'game' did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock value. I was not shocked nor emotionally moved in any way by this. Maybe I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simple to provoke a reaction out of me. As for the other half of the game, it attempts to paint a picture (literally) of a person in mental decline. It deals with obsession, hallucination, depression, and a few other themes. In theory, it is an interesting idea. But the 'game' took me 10 minutes to complete, and that includes reading and absorbing every little detail I could.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then steps back. It is an excellent way to test your mind while still being fun. Although this game isn't as story-heavy, it did give rise to one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play this game and complete it when I am feeling bored, and I love to return and see what created a legend and what remains a legend. Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is quite simple, to explain at least. You use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate part of the puzzle. Two buttons are in the game, one that you press and one that requires a cube to place on.

If you can overlook the bugs (which I personally only encountered two: one minor and the other quite annoying) edit: both bugs are resolved—one fix boosted my fps from 60-90 to 80-120—and are looking for a space exploration game, I can definitely recommend this. Since most of these reviews focus on specs, I'll include mine: i5 6600k (~200€), Radeon RX480 (~200€), Z170 Pro-Gaming (~150€), 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€). ~650€ is definitely within the mid-range price bracket, though, granted, this rig is fairly new. Almost constant 60+ fps on high settings with Vsync enabled—I genuinely can't believe 90% of the comments claiming they're running an overkill setup and get 20fps.

Remember Age of Mythology? Yeah, it's been that long since there's been an RTS game of such quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes awfully close to the borders of my personal favorite RTS game. Combine this with a huge Risk-like grand strategy mode and there, it hits the spot. I am not (read: try not to be) overly biased due to the fact that this game allows you to turn into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking, and even commanding unit production, direction, and spawning simultaneously. Honestly, I do like the complicated RTS games nowadays. Think of Civ V and so on. However, such games attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts, and resources all into one overwhelming game mode.

Undertale comes together to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title and the music is pleasant, but paired together they craft some truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script runs the gamut from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, and achieves this while turning RPG tropes on their head. And all of this without touching on the world, characters, story, gameplay... I could write whole pages about it. But instead, I'll just say this: if you like RPGs, play this game. If you enjoy video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your death, play this game.

I have only had this game for a few months, but in just that short period, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The devs are very active in the community, and it really shows in the various discussion forums and dev diaries. There is a fairly steep learning curve to the game's mechanics, which I am still trying to master; however, this depth of strategy allows you countless ways to achieve goals and capitalize on certain situations. The game, in my opinion, is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself engrossed in every session I play regardless of how the play-through unfolds.

Warframe is a fun game for the first few hours of play. After those enjoyable hours, you'll begin to notice that the only thing left the game offers is repetition in its combat, enemies, and gameplay. The major highlight is that the developers work hard and provide semi-frequent updates, often including substantial content from sweeping changes to game systems, new warframes, and other tweaks or features. It's a good game to play casually. Though I doubt it will hold your attention beyond a few months unless you truly enjoy grinding. The upside is that the game is free, so I'd recommend trying it. If you're looking for a quick fix, give it a shot.

This game is so... very... boring. I bought this game because I believed it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy,' a popular and fun PS2 game. Sadly, it's far from it. In this game, you go around absorbing ever bigger things to grow larger and absorb bigger objects. But the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be, the levels lack creativity, and what is there feels like a surreal horror show. I don't mean an entertaining horror show but one that makes you feel depressed and question whether being alive is worth it. Every 'living' creature in this game, from small pets to human beings, makes me wonder if the creators had an interest in taxidermy.

Alright. Let me explain a few things. As a person very interested in politics, I was very intrigued by this game when I first heard about it. I thought, "Oh wow! A simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds fun!" Well, it really wasn't. The game starts you off and says you need to pick a side: Republican or Democrat—there is no independent or third party. A little disappointed, but still optimistic, I carried on to see what I could do. I will give the game credit: the character customization, although limited, is pretty fun to mess around with. It's the only time it's an option to wear your head or not in a campaign. Literally.

Fallout 3's story was better. Settlements interfere with the story to the point you'll resent managing them instead of enjoying the narrative. Some keys are hard coded and cannot be rebound. Bugs galore. My pipboy vanished permanently at one point, forcing me to research console commands to restore it. You don’t have to earn power armor—it’s practically handed to you early in the game, and power cores are abundant in trader shops. The value of power armor is greatly diminished compared to previous Fallout titles. The story is mediocre, and nearly everything about this game is average, except it doesn’t crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3. It’s far more stable than Fallout 3. Is it better than Fallout 3? No. Is it better than New Vegas? No. This title was massively overhyped for how disappointing it truly is.

My stats (at the time of writing this review):  
- 8.6 hrs to reach the end  
- 10 collectibles found out of 25  
- zero achievements out of 15  

What I liked:  
- Visuals up until the last level (ice caves)  
- Story isn't that great, but the ending (after the credits) made me not regret spending time on this game  

What I disliked:  
- Visuals in the last level are dull  
- Gameplay in the last level becomes much harder, turning it into a frustrating experience of repeating tasks until perfected  
- Achievements are too difficult. There are 13 (out of 15) that fewer than 2.1% of players have unlocked!

Pros: +graphic  
Cons:  
-bugs (especially in the environment; you may get stuck or your shots may hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight to the enemy)  
-game is overly handholding/babysitting you  
-dumb AI  
-enemies always seem to know your location once spotted  
-godlike enemy accuracy, which is as frustrating as in the first Ghost Warrior  
-terrible checkpoints and saves  
-boring story that I couldn't care less about  
Will not recommend unless it's 90% off—even then, playing this game feels like a tedious chore, just finishing it to move on to the next in my library. Given the time wasted on the first Ghost Warrior (equally dull, and I felt liberated upon completing it), I likely won't play this one to the end.

Review for 29/11/2015: Do not buy this game, servers are offline. You can't play. No compres este juego, servidores offline. No puedes jugar. While I could play it, I enjoyed it. As the song by the Steve Miller Band...: go on take the money and run uh uh uhhh! go on take the money and run go on take the money and run go on take the money and run https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54 --- English - 73 minutes playing the game OMFG just an hour in this game! It's awesome! Some guns are OP and matchmaking is sometimes unfair, but hey, BF3 has worse matchmaking. A newbie and the higher-level players weren't real humans—you shot them in the face and nothing happens!

Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? :d This puzzle platforming game stars a little guy with a fez who explores a vast branching map while collecting fragments to form a cube. This game is quite entertaining and completing it was a lot of fun. ^_^ However, it can become somewhat frustrating if you aim to collect all the cubes and achievements. To unlock every cube, you'll need to solve cryptic codes. These can take mere seconds or push you to consult a guide (*raises hand* I gave up. -_-). The guide, 'a complete guide to fez!!!'

It's not hard for me to see why other people like this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing, I have a Vive and I'm much more interested in playing room-scale games with the controllers. Beyond that, the game is initially awe-inspiring in the scale of its universe, but I also felt that same scale was a hindrance to my enjoyment. The learning curve and the amount of time required to do anything interesting at the beginning were both too steep for me. Perhaps if I were more patient and had more time for gaming, this would be compelling to me. But I don't have either, and there are plenty more VR games I'd rather spend my time on.

Hands down my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun rambos need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always result in death unless it just grazes you. Rounds drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are required if you wish to stay on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload halfway through your magazine constantly, you will have a pouch full of half-empty mags. You can't run forever. If you sprint for a while, your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you catch your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a windowsill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.

Let me start off by saying I did not purchase EU when it first came out and that I got it on sale, which included EW, so I never experienced the issues some people claim to have had with that game. I loved that game, however; it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right. As for XCOM 2, I love it—the game runs pretty well for me on medium, and I’m using a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. At first, the game set it to high, and it ran a bit sluggishly but not to the point of being unplayable. When I dropped it down to medium, it smoothed out. Not sure if I’m just lucky when it comes to having issues with games or what, but most of the negative reviews sound like they’re coming from some really entitled people.

+rpg leveling +wide variety of ship types +physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles +easy-to-learn resource management +dark humor -grind intensive (if underutilizing the civvy station types) -subpar ai teammates -low variety of equipment types -limited variety of leveling skills (that is, no branching) listen, this game is fun as hell. Despite my minuses up there, there is still some variety and strategy to be had. It starts off fast and really picks up. Even though there's a low variety of equipment, it still feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to extend the life of this game is the mods. Fight for universe is easily the star, but big fight for beef is also very good.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty as more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe arrive in the Swiss mountain resort Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's economic influence to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the more than 20 government and state leaders attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be subdued. Anti-globalization campaigners have canceled a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, scheduled to coincide with the WEF's more exclusive event in Davos.

Deadline nears for Fiat-GM deal Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on 1 February to resolve a disagreement over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, part of an alliance agreed in 2000. GM, whose own European operations are losing money, no longer wants to acquire the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent Fiat shares down 1.2% on Tuesday, after Monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payout. The US firm is thought to be offering about $2bn (£1.06bn) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued the deal was voided by Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and halve GM's stake via a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to ally with Fiat.

Cardinal criticises Iraq war cost: billions of pounds spent on conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to reduce poverty, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has said. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales made the comments on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance in his Christmas midnight mass. The cardinal used a Christmas message to denounce the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the Archbishop of Canterbury have both spoken out about the war. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's *Thought for the Day* slot, he criticised the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to lift people "out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease". The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make poverty history".

British stars denied major Oscars: British hopes of winning major Oscars were dashed as UK stars failed to secure acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's *Vera Drake* missed the director or screenplay awards, and there was no prize for star Imelda Staunton. Kate Winslet also lost to Best Actress Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo failed to win Best Supporting Actor awards. The UK's Andrea Arnold won the short film award for her gritty drama *Wasp*. Arnold, who hosted children's television shows *Number 73* and *Motormouth* in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. *Wasp* tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, defeating films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Halloween writer Debra Hill dies. Screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, best known for her work on the 70s horror classic Halloween, has died in Los Angeles at age 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it earned over $60m (£31.3m) worldwide—a record for independent film at that time. Hill also worked with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way up, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before collaborating with Carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on roles in the 70s that were more commonly held by men.

Broadband fuels online expression as fast web access is encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and maintain personal sites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. It stated that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the UK have broadband, and that number is growing rapidly. The Demos report examined the impact of broadband on people's online habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to waking up in the middle of the night to browse the web. More significantly, argues the report, broadband is motivating people to take a more active role online.

Yukos heading back to US courts Russian oil and gas company Yukos is due in a US court on Thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is in the process of being broken up by Russian authorities to pay a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. The unit was however sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm Rosneft but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now claim the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to pursue any company that buys its assets, using all available legal means.

Voters flock to blog awards site as voting is under way for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best web blogs—online spaces where people share their thoughts—of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed due to excessive visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a leading US dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and reports that over 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to US research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life, but fewer than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing'—the China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to comply with a government order to halt construction of one of its massive dams, the Chinese state press has reported. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the sister Xiluodu Dam, according to the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 large-scale construction projects suspended due to insufficient environmental reviews. The Beijing News stated the company may opt to pay a fine instead. The firm has also disregarded orders to cease construction at two other projects—the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects flagged by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for lacking mandatory environmental impact assessments have adhered to the shutdown order.

Man City 0-2 Man Utd Manchester United narrowed Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which deflected off Richard Dunne, to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes United had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to sustain any hope of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more labored than patient, and they managed to create just one chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Wales 'must learn health lessons' as the new health minister for Wales says there are lessons to learn from England in tackling waiting lists. Dr Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the role after Jane Hutt was dismissed, acknowledged "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. But both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats said Dr Gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile Ms Hutt defended her record, stating waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr Gibbons, who was a GP in Blaengwynfi, in the Upper Afan Valley, before becoming AM for Aberavon, said NHS staff wanted a period of stability after "tremendous change and reform." One of the biggest problems which had faced Ms Hutt during her five-and-a-half years as the assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson hails Man Utd's resolve Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has praised his players' resilient performance in the 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away game of the season and it was a thrilling match, end-to-end with plenty of good passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed great character and determination and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come and Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also lauded senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed and which no other player has got.

Singer's film to screen at festival: a documentary that takes a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be shown at this year's Berlin Film Festival. *A Different Story* will screen in the Panorama section of the festival, which runs from 10–20 February. It features the singer discussing both his career and personal life, from his days in Wham! through to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February. Director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens will also attend the event. The 93-minute film will show Michael reflecting on his early days in Wham! along with his later career, including his legal battles with record label Sony and his stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads enter US singles chart as digital music downloads are being included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green Day's *Boulevard of Broken Dreams* is currently number two in Billboard's Pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are set to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be combined with sales of physical singles and airplay data to create its new Hot 100 chart. Its second new chart—the Pop 100—also merges airplay, digital and physical sales but limits its airplay data to US radio stations that play chart music.

Anti-spam laws bite spammer hard as the net's self-declared spam king seeks bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the man behind OptInRealBig.com and billions of junk mail messages, said lawsuits had forced the company into Chapter 11. OptInRealBig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. The company stated that filing for Chapter 11 would help it attempt to resolve its legal problems while continuing operations. Listed as the third biggest spammer globally by junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, OptInRealBig was sued in December 2003 for sending messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was filed by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who alleged that Mr. Richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini. Tottenham sporting director Frank Arnesen has dismissed claims that coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been newspaper speculation that Santini had felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "There is only one thing that made him resign and that is his own personal problems. He has talked to me recently and said this matter is entirely for himself." Arnesen said he was unable to shed any light on the problems that caused Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added: "Jacques has never gone into exactly what it was. But I trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.

Ireland surged past Scotland as Ireland maintained their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory over Scotland at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and another penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will attempt to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy visit Edinburgh, but they again struggled to turn pressure into points.

Economy focus for election battle Britain's economic future will be at the heart of Labour's poll campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has said. He was speaking after cabinet members held their final meeting at No 10 before the expected election announcement. He stated voters would recognize that Labour had delivered stability and growth, and would continue to do so. Meanwhile the Tories outlined their plans to tackle "yob culture" and the Lib Dems provided more details about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three parties urging them not to fight the election by exploiting people's fears. In an open letter, he called on them not to turn the election into a contest about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Brizzel to race in AAA's in Sheffield. Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA Championships. US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not race in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy will aim to secure his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in tremendous form on the European circuit in recent weeks. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and already seems assured of a place in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg in the European Championships. Carroll is ranked number three in the world 3000m rankings at the moment, with Cragg occupying top spot.

Robinson aims for dual code success as England rugby union captain Jason Robinson has targeted dual code success over Australia on Saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, will lead England against Australia at Twickenham at 1430 GMT. Later at 1815 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team faces Australia in the final of the Tri-Nations tournament. "Beating the Aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said Robinson. England have the opportunity to secure their third autumn international victory after successive wins over Canada and South Africa, as well as gaining revenge for June's 51-15 hammering by the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end 34 years of defeat against Australia with victory at Elland Road.

Warning over tsunami aid website: Net users are being warned to avoid a scam website that claims to collect cash on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears plausible because it uses an old version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, DEC has no connection with the fake site and states it has contacted the police about it. The site is just the latest in a long list of scams that try to exploit the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is included in a spam email that is currently circulating. The message's subject line reads "urgent tsunami earthquake appeal" and its text contains all the poor grammar and bad spelling that characterises many other phishing attempts.

Iraq to invite phone licence bids Iraq is to invite bids for two telephone licences, aiming to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, Arab and foreign companies, Iraq's Ministry of Communications said. The winner will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, offering voice, fax and internet services. The ministry stated that it aimed to increase Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years." It also hopes to establish a "highly visible and competitive telecommunication sector." Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February. It is also planning a road-show for investors in Amman, Jordan.

More women turn to net security as older people and women are increasingly taking charge of protecting home computers against malicious online attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing programs to safeguard PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted for net security firm Preventon, reveals that security messages are reaching a diverse range of internet users. It is estimated that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired. Over the past three years, that figure has increased by an average of 13.2%. However, more retired women (53%) purchased security software than retired men. The research reflects shifting stereotypes and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the heightened risks that high-speed broadband connections can pose to users.

Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can hold up to 10,000 songs, which is a lot of space to fill. But more and more iPod owners are using that space for audio content created by an unpredictable assortment of producers. It is called 'podcasting,' and its strongest advocate is former MTV host and VJ (video jockey) Adam Curry. Podcasting takes its name from the Apple iPod, although you do not need an iPod to create or listen to a podcast. A podcast is essentially an internet-based radio show that podcasters produce, often in the comfort of their own home. They need only a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet, and others can download and listen to them, all for free.

Levy wins Whitbread novel prize Orange Prize winner Andrea Levy has seen her book *Small Island* claim the Whitbread Novel of the Year Award. She is now the frontrunner to win the overall prize after defeating Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's *The Line of Beauty*. Geraldine McCaughrean has secured the children's fiction award for the third time with *Not the End of the World*. All the category winners advance to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which includes a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges featuring Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris will convene on 25 January to choose the overall winner, with the announcement made later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has ranked London-based Levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win.

Yukos seeks court action on sale Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the obscure firm which purchased its main asset. Yukos has stated it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to freeze Baikal's assets after the Russian government disregarded a US court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for acquiring the unit remain unclear. Russian newspapers have alleged that Baikal - which bought the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4bn (261bn roubles, £4.8bn) on Sunday at a state-run auction - has strong ties with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts 2-1 Livingston  
Hearts secured their Scottish Cup quarter-final victory against Livingston with two early goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller struck within the opening minute, heading over Colin Meldrum from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister added the second, meeting Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post to extend their lead. Craig Easton pulled one back with a disputed header after an hour, but Hearts held firm. The opener came after Gus Bahoken fouled Miller 35 yards out. McAllister delivered the free kick into the box, and Miller outjumped the static defense to loop his header over Meldrum. Just 10 minutes in, the hosts doubled their advantage. Mikoliunas raced down the right and crossed to the back post, where McAllister powered his header past Meldrum.

Sun offers processing by the hour. Sun Microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service that will allow customers requiring massive computing power to rent it by the hour. Sun Grid costs users $1 (53p) for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by Sun. So-called grid computing is the latest buzz phrase in a company which believes that computing capacity is as essential a commodity as hardware and software. Sun likened grid computing to the evolution of electricity. The system could mature in the same way utilities such as electricity and water have developed, said Sun's chief operating officer Jonathan Schwartz. 'Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?' he asked in a webcast launching Sun's quarterly network computing event in California.

Jamieson issues warning to bigots: Scotland's justice minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she intends to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson said exclusion orders are among a series of measures being considered in the Scottish executive's campaign against sectarianism. She praised Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in tackling the problem. However, the minister stated that stopping sectarian abuse linked to Old Firm matches is a key objective. Ms Jamieson was speaking ahead of the third-round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a major target for the executive. Last week Ms Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

UK debut for Kevin Spacey movie Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of their new film, *Beyond the Sea*, in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. 'This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent,' said Spacey, who, as Darin, sings all 18 songs on the film soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife—real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. 'I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan,' said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with British boyfriend Orlando Bloom.

Leeds v Saracens (Fri) Headingley Friday, 25 February 2000 GMT The Tykes have brought in Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre. - Friday's game at Headingley was given the go-ahead after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an unclear future as the fixed-line phone in your home could soon become an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia reveals that more and more people are using their mobile phones for every call they make or take. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now rely solely on a mobile. It indicated that people keep their fixed-line phone because call charges are lower, but most respondents said the future was undoubtedly mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research showed that mobiles and fixed phones served different purposes. Home phones were used for longer calls, while conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, often between mobiles and to friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents said they preferred their fixed phone because it remained cheaper to use than a mobile.

Melzer shocks Agassi as second seed Andre Agassi suffered a comprehensive defeat by Jurgen Melzer in the quarter-finals of the SAP Open. Agassi was repeatedly bamboozled by the Austrian's drop shots in San Jose, losing 6-3 6-1. Defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick rallied to beat Sweden's Thomas Enqvist 3-6 7-6 (8-6) 7-5. But unseeded Cyril Saulnier defeated the fourth seed Vincent Spadea 6-2 6-4, and Tommy Haas overcame eighth seed Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7) 7-6 (7-3) 6-2. Melzer has now beaten Agassi in two of their three meetings. "I had a solid game plan and executed it perfectly," he said. "It's always tough to face Andre. I didn't want him to play his game. He makes you run like a dog all over the court."

MPs tout Lords replacement plan: A group of MPs has sought to increase the pressure on Tony Blair over reform to the House of Lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber in which 70% of members would be elected. MPs and peers have failed to agree on reform since 1999 when 600 hereditaries lost their seats. The group claims it can secure support for removing the last 92 hereditaries. The government delayed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers because they said they were unlikely to succeed after opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has argued there needs to be consensus on reforms. There have been suggestions that proposals for changing at least the powers of the Lords will appear in Labour's manifesto.

Disappointed Scott in solid start Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships following a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot placed fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. 'It was definitely a learning curve, and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week,' said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who matched the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his performance in the final. He won his heat in 7.64secs but ran 0.04secs slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final.

A US woman sues over cartridges: a US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), claiming its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date. The unnamed woman from Georgia alleges that a chip inside the cartridge signals the printer that it needs refilling even when it does not. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges use a chip technology to detect when they are low on ink and prompt the user to make a change. But the suit claims the chips also disable the cartridges at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are empty.

Virgin Radio offers 3G broadcast. UK broadcaster Virgin Radio says it will become the first station globally to deliver radio via 3G mobiles. The radio station, in partnership with technology firm Sydus, will transmit on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year listeners will be able to download software from the Virgin website which enables the service. James Cridland, head of new media at Virgin Radio, said: "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station made available, followed by two digital stations, Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr Cridland said: "This application will allow anyone, anywhere to listen to Virgin Radio simply with the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music is on the Isle of Wight bill. Roxy Music will appear at June's Isle of Wight Music Festival, along with Morrissey, Supergrass and Idlewild. REM have already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, which takes place from 10–12 June. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will take to the stage on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is also working in the studio on new material, their first since the 1982 album *Avalon*. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's *Virginia Plain*, with other hits including *Street Life*, *Love Is the Drug*, and the 1981 John Lennon cover, *Jealous Guy*.

Captains lining up for the aid match include Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll, one of four Six Nations captains selected for the Northern Hemisphere squad in the IRB Rugby Aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Gordon Bullock of Scotland, and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also in the Northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod MacQueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he said. It will be a chance for Woodward to evaluate some of his options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he said.

Spirit awards hail *Sideways* The comedy *Sideways* has dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six of the awards for which it was nominated. It was named best film while Alexander Payne won best director and best screenplay, along with writing partner Jim Taylor. It also won acting awards for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church and Virginia Madsen. *Sideways* is tipped to do well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, honor films made outside the traditional studio system, and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who took best actress for her role as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama *Maria Full of Grace*. Moreno is also nominated for best actress at the Oscars. The best first screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for *Maria Full of Grace*.

Prince was crowned 'top music earner' after earning more than any other pop star in 2004, surpassing artists like Madonna and Elton John in *Rolling Stone* magazine's annual list. The singer banked $56.5m (£30.4m) from concerts, album and publishing sales with his *Musicology* tour and album. He kept Madonna in second place, as she earned $54.9m (£29.5m) while embarking on her global *Re-Invention* tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel ranked 10th, their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9m (£13.4m) last year. "Prince returned to center stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine reported. The singer's 2004 tour grossed $90.3m (£48.5m) in ticket sales, and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album *Musicology*.

Irish band U2 have been honoured at France's biggest music awards, but were beaten to a prize by boy band Blue. U2 received a special achievement award at the NRJ Music Awards, but Blue claimed the international group title. US band Maroon 5 was named best new international artist and won the best international song prize for *This Love*. More than five million radio listeners voted in the awards. The international male and female prizes went to Usher and Avril Lavigne respectively. Collecting his band's award from model Naomi Campbell at the Cannes ceremony, U2 frontman Bono said in French: *"I'm not from this country but I'll make a little confession to you—it's on the Côte d'Azur I feel at home."*

Tories outlining policing plans: local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under proposals unveiled by the Conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard said the new role would replace "invisible" police authorities. He stated the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The Lib Dems argued the plan could let extreme groups run policing, while Labour criticised "costly" Tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank-and-file officers, said it was essential operational independence was retained. Jan Berry said: "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches. These plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground," she warned.

At a glance: Tory health checks The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's an overview of the plan: People coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with high rates of TB, they would need a chest x-ray and further tests if necessary. All individuals from outside the European Union who wish to stay a year or longer will have to undergo a full medical. Tuberculosis, hepatitis B and HIV. A positive test for TB would automatically result in visa applications being rejected. All other conditions would be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

Paris promise lifts Welsh hopes. Has there been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic in Paris? And can the Welsh revival continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978? Those are the two questions occupying not just Wales supporters but rugby fans worldwide after a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two of three Grand Slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades." Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games I have ever played in." A crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed: "There was a French half and there was a Welsh half."

Doves soar to UK album summit. Manchester rock band Doves have entered the UK album chart at number one with their new release, *Some Cities*. The trio replace flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the top. The album follows the single *Black and White Town*, which reached number six. R&B star Nelly claims the new number one single with *Over and Over*, featuring Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs all have new singles in the top ten, alongside Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, *(Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame*, entered the chart at number three, one place ahead of Girls Aloud's *Wake Me Up*. Hip-hop performer Akon's *Locked Up* is at number five, while hotly-tipped Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs secure their second chart hit at number six with *Oh My God*.

Davies favours Gloucester future Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to stay with English side Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are keen on the 32-year-old, but that he would prefer to remain where he is. Davies, one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is only on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. But the hooker has proved his value to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to secure a new deal next season. The summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left Davies in the cold and forced him to accept a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he got match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, he admitted before his move to Gloucester that he was frustrated with the way he was treated.

Cabinet anger at Brown cash raid Ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall funds to keep council tax bills down, Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Mr Raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. But he stressed that local governments must deliver good services without significant council tax increases. The central government funding is part of a £1bn package to help local authorities in England limit next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr Raynsford said nearly all central government departments had an interest in well-run local authorities.

Israeli club look to Africa as four African players, including Zimbabwe goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, are set to play for Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin are the first Arab side ever to compete in European competition and will face English Premiership side Newcastle United in the first round. Warriors' goalkeeper Murambadoro, who made a name for himself at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, helped Bnei Sakhnin defeat Albania's Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro moved to Israel recently after a brief stint with South African club Hellenic. The club won the Israeli Cup final last season and are based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. The club has a strong ethic and is a prominent promoter of peace and co-operation within Israel.

New drink limit 'would cut toll'—more lives than previously thought could be saved by reducing drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University College London research claims lowering the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, states cutting the limit would also result in 230 fewer serious injuries on the UK's roads compared with 2003. He estimates that this would save the country £119m a year. A previous estimate, included in a 1998 Department of Transport document, suggested such a move could save 50 lives a year.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design offers a large detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time required for the voltage to return to its baseline. This eliminates the need for power-hungry and bulky analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the entire system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been demonstrated to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that incentivizes AVs to adopt centrally controlled system optimal (SO) routing by saving on tolls, while user equilibrium (UE) seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, where dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, and the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering a mixed fleet of AVs and HVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. Beyond coaxing ever larger and more tangible objects into a regime of quantum behavior, this new capability has inspired ideas of using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity prevents access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Indeed, early optomechanical proposals noted the possibility to overcome this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, these have not yet achieved nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews provide product evaluations for customers to make decisions. Unfortunately, the evaluations can be manipulated using fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers, who have developed increasingly insidious and powerful spamming strategies by adapting to the deployed detectors. Spamming strategies are difficult to capture, as they can vary rapidly over time, differ across spammers and target products, and more critically, remain unknown in most cases. Furthermore, most existing detectors focus on detection accuracy, which is not well-aligned with the goal of maintaining the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address these challenges, we formulate a minimax game where the spammers and spam detectors compete with each other on their practical objectives that are not solely based on detection accuracy. Nash equilibria of the game lead to robust detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer in a 3-level quantum system with lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we employ the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions enabling exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to simultaneously control the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation in the pulse areas at which the infidelity exceeds $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we study the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function for Gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to nonconvexity, there exist multiple local minima that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We demonstrate that all local minima share the same structural form, which partially identifies the component centers of the true mixture. Specifically, each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our results apply to the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition and remain valid even when the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we derive sharper results in terms of the scaling with the separation between the components.

We consider the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold.
