This orbifold is defined as a quotient by some suitable subgroup $G$ of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface $X_m$ in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $W_m$. The first, Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $X_{m^t}$ inside it by some dual group $G^t$. In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide a simple proof of the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this work, a generalization of the study of human gait was derived from existing models in the literature, such as those of Keller and Kockshenev. In this hybrid model, a strategy of metabolic energy minimization is combined in a race process, with a non-linear description of the movement of the mass center's libration, aiming to reproduce the behavior of the walk-run transition. The results of the experimental data, for different speed regimes, indicate that the perimeter of the trajectory of the mass center is a relevant quantity in the quantification of this dynamic. An experimental procedure was implemented in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and laboratories of the Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

We present a new mixed variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems that fully resolves close encounters. The method is based on a time regularization that preserves the stability properties of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size during planetary encounters. We employ a high-order MVS scheme, enabling integration with large time steps far from close encounters. We demonstrate that this algorithm can resolve near-exact collisions (i.e., with a mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius) while maintaining the same time-step as in weakly perturbed systems like the solar system. We illustrate the long-term behavior using systems of six super-Earths undergoing strong scattering for 50 kyr. We compare our algorithm to hybrid methods such as Mercury and show that for equivalent computational cost, we achieve significantly better energy conservation.

Entanglement is a key resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In reality, due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert-space dimension with respect to the system size, it is very challenging to construct an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states only needs two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution for an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, which has a distinct multipolar structure determined solely by its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a broad family of horizonless microstate geometries. The latter can violate the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric and exhibit a far richer multipolar structure, offering a pathway to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. We find numerical evidence that all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with identical mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates can impose only weak constraints on fuzzballs, while future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the space mission LISA will refine these bounds by orders of magnitude.

Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a challenging task in many domains, such as bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We consider a common scenario in which edges can represent short-term interactions (e.g., messaging) or long-term structural connections (e.g., friendship). In practice, long-term edges are often specified by humans. Human-specified edges can be both costly to produce and suboptimal for the downstream task. To address these issues, we propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication. Since temporal attention drives feature propagation between nodes, using the dynamics of node interactions to learn this key component offers more flexibility while simultaneously avoiding issues associated with human-specified edges.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibration of a photonic crystal waveguide (pcw) are reported. The pcw consists of two parallel nanobeams separated by a 240 nm vacuum gap. Models are developed and validated for the transduction of beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (gm) of the pcw for probe frequencies far from and near the dielectric band edge. Since our pcw has been designed for near-field atom trapping, this research provides a foundation for evaluating potential deleterious effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of pcws. Long-term goals include achieving strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the gms of the pcw, thereby enabling optomechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in these splittings arises from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor, so the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences split into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings imply the regularity of various Euler classes related to the tautological representations of $O(n)$ and $U(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects lead to a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression is a significant source of uncertainty for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys such as *Euclid* or *LSST*. In this first paper of a two-part series, we use simulations to construct a *Euclid*-like tomographic mock dataset for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, which are both adjusted for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). Additionally, we develop an emulator to generate rapid predictions of the baryonic power suppression, enabling us to conduct a likelihood inference analysis for a standard $\Lambda$CDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings such as those captured in child-centered recordings have been shown to be among the most challenging audio files to process. Nevertheless, developing speech processing models capable of handling such a wide variety of conditions would be particularly valuable for language acquisition studies in which researchers are interested in the quantity and quality of the speech that children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and assessing effects of remediation. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To this end, we compiled diverse child-centered corpora which amount to a total of 260 hours of recordings and cover 10 languages.

Density-based clustering relies on the idea of linking groups to certain specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. The reference to a true, yet unknown, population structure allows us to frame the clustering problem in a standard inferential setting, where the concept of ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation of this approach, known as modal clustering, establishes a correspondence between the groups and the domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is required, and a proper selection of the amount of smoothing, which governs the shape of the density and thus possibly the modal structure, is crucial to identify the final partition. In this work, we address the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between Standard Model and higher-dimension operators parameterizing the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for the diboson scattering amplitudes create an obstruction to the na\"ive interference contributions of dimension-six operators, causing the total diboson rate correction's leading contribution to cancel. In this case, precisely measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, restoring sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail, and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by the construction of an asymmetry variable which is only generated by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same level as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is the goal of many data analyses in the health and social sciences. However, academic statistics has often frowned upon data analyses with a causal objective. The emergence of the term "data science" provides a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis in such a way that it naturally accommodates causal inference from observational data. Like others before, we categorize the scientific contributions of data science into three classes of tasks: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (which includes causal inference). A clear classification of data science tasks is necessary to discuss the data, assumptions, and analytics required to successfully accomplish each task. We argue that a failure to adequately describe the role of subject-matter expert knowledge in data analysis is a source of widespread misunderstandings about data science.

The weak gravity conjecture (WGC) demands the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The standard lore is that these particles are introduced to ensure that extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but it is unclear what is wrong if this does not occur. This note demonstrates that, for a generic Einstein quantum theory of gravity in AdS, exact stability of extremal black branes conflicts with rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy. Avoiding the contradiction leads to a nonperturbative version of the WGC, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general and does not rely on either supersymmetry or a specific UV completion, assuming only the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can give rise to unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures remains one of the major unsolved problems in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to investigate the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, but direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. Here, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity v$_{\rm c}$. We measure v$_{\rm c}$ as a function of interaction strength and find a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our results establish ultracold Fermi gases as a powerful platform for studying the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

Ordinary differential equation (ODE) is a mathematical model used in various application areas such as climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering due to its intuitive appeal for modeling. Despite ODE's wide usage in modeling, the frequent absence of analytic solutions makes it challenging to estimate ODE parameters from the data, particularly when the model has many variables and parameters. This paper proposes a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that is fast and accurate even for models with numerous parameters. The proposed method approximates an ODE model with a state-space model based on equations of a numerical solver. It enables fast estimation by avoiding computations of a full numerical solution in the likelihood. The posterior is obtained by a variational Bayes method, more specifically, the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method (Honkela et al.).

We study the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in nsn junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) in proximity to an $s$-wave superconductor. We find that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes strongly depend on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We analyze the influence of a chiral chemical potential, i.e., the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, on the transport characteristics of the junction. Notably, we observe a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs that are generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions. The spin polarization is opposite in the two WSM regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been demonstrated to be an effective and controllable technique for modifying the surface electrical conductivity of the ceramic piece, and this approach has been used in numerous applications. Importantly, it provides a method for grading the voltage drop across high-voltage insulators, thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied without surface flashover. However, a concern regarding this method is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, particularly if the implanted metal species is easily oxidized. Here we report on our investigation of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. The results indicate that after an initial drop of as much as 40% in the first few weeks following implantation, the conductivity exhibits only a very gradual decrease of about 10% over the subsequent year.

We introduce a novel skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons based on the concept of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. Moreover, there exist singular configurations that can be identified as n_f=1 baryons charged under the new symmetry. Under this identification, the vector mesons act as the Chern-Simons vector fields residing on the quantum Hall droplet that forms the n_f=1 baryon. We propose that this current represents the correct effective expression for the baryon current at low energies. This proposal provides a unified description for the two types of baryons and enables them to continuously transform into one another in a natural way. Furthermore, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a consequence of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions offers an intriguing way to combine anomalous Hall and Josephson physics in a single device. We study theoretically how the superposition of both effects influences superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions' transport properties. Transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface generates sizable transverse Hall supercurrents, which we refer to as anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We generalize the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, initially developed to quantify conventional (tunneling) Josephson currents, to evaluate the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes are highly tunable through the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a distinct spectroscopic fingerprint of Josephson junctions, well-localized subgap bound states form near the interface.

Following the suggestion from the Monte Carlo experiments in Jiménez (J. Turbul. 2020), that dipoles are as significant to the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence as individual vortex cores, it is found that the kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed by the merging of dipoles. Vortices separate into a group of small fast-moving cores, and another group of larger slowly moving ones, which can be described as 'frozen' into a gradually evolving 'crystal'. The kinematics of both groups are quite distinct, and only the former is self-similar. The latter accounts for most of the kinetic energy of the flow, and its vortices form the dipoles and the streams. Mechanisms are discussed for the growth of this slow component.

Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be an extremely useful framework for designing several quantum algorithms. Often, the running time of quantum algorithms in this framework is characterized by the quantum hitting time: the time required for the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with high probability. In this article, we present improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time that can be applied to several ctqw-based quantum algorithms. In particular, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, improving its hitting time upper bound by a polynomial factor: from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$. Furthermore, our methods also help exponentially improve the precision dependence of the continuous-time quantum walk based algorithm to find a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain by Chakraborty et al.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or the "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously considered as the main EMRI sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. In this letter, we highlight an alternative EMRI formation channel: (wet) EMRI formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes that are initially moving on inclined orbits, and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the MBH—this process enhances the formation rate of EMRIs in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have no information about them, i.e. no interaction with items, no user profile, and no social links with other users. Under such circumstances, we still expect our recommender systems to attract the users initially so they decide to stay on the website and become active users. This problem falls into the new user cold-start category and is crucial to the development and even survival of a company. Existing works on user cold-start recommendation either require additional user efforts, e.g. setting up an interview process, or utilize side information [10] such as user demographics, locations, social relations, etc. However, users may not be willing to take the interview, and side information for cold-start users is often unavailable.

Deep learning has solved many problems that are beyond the reach of heuristic algorithms. It has also been successfully applied in wireless communications, even though current radio systems are well-understood and optimal algorithms exist for many tasks. While some gains have been achieved by learning individual parts of a receiver, a better approach is to jointly learn the entire receiver. This, however, often results in a challenging nonlinear problem, for which the optimal solution is impractical to implement. To this end, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, deeprx, which executes the entire receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5G-compliant fashion. We enable accurate channel estimation by constructing the input of the convolutional neural network in a very specific manner using both the data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically uses an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) from which to generate new inputs by mutation. A corpus of potential seeds often contains thousands of similar inputs. This lack of diversity can lead to wasted fuzzing effort through exhaustive mutation of all available seeds. To address this, fuzzers include distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest subset of seeds triggering the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. Common practice suggests that minimizing the number and cumulative size of the seeds improves fuzzing efficiency, which we explore systematically. We present results of 34+ cpu-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches to evaluate their impact on finding bugs in real-world software.

In this paper we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be divided into several groups in each of which the agents have similar (isomorphic) state transition structures, and thus can be relabeled into the same template. Based on the template, a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost remain independent of the number of agents is designed for partial observation. The scalable supervisor under partial observation does not require recomputation regardless of how many agents are added to or removed from the system. We extend our earlier results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor on the template level. An example is provided to demonstrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations constitute a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for ENF estimation is introduced with temporal windowing based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. A form of Gohberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is used due to the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. Moreover, this approach employs, for the first time in the field of ENF, a temporal window, not necessarily rectangular, at the stage preceding spectral estimation. Krylov matrices are utilized for fast implementation of matrix inversions. The proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in ENF estimation when a short time window of $1$ second is used in power recordings. In speech recordings, the proposed approach yields highly accurate results in terms of both time complexity and accuracy.

The direpack package aims to introduce a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into the Python ecosystem as a single, consistent package. The dimension reduction methods included fall into three categories: projection pursuit based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. As a corollary, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are provided as well, ranging from classical principal component regression up to sparse partial robust M regression. The package also includes a set of classical and robust pre-processing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, along with dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Finally, direpack has been designed consistent with the scikit-learn API, ensuring the estimators can seamlessly be integrated into (statistical and/or machine) learning pipelines within that framework.

The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely applied for high spatial resolution optical imaging. Here, we investigated the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect of the nitrogen vacancy defect in diamond. The fluorescence reduction was observed under high power laser excitation. It enhanced the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission and altered the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. We employed a differential excitation protocol to extract the high spatial frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser's power, the spatial resolution of imaging was improved approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Due to the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, we expect this method can be utilized for improving the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling with defects in solids.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the standard approach of using individual survey weights (constructed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer yields asymptotically unbiased inference. We develop a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that ensures unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. We compare our approach with frequentist methods that depend on numerical integration to show that only the Bayesian method achieves both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real data example for a survey of business establishments demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach across different modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a culmination of recent developmental efforts that integrate traditional survey estimation approaches with the Bayesian modeling framework and provides a connection between these two rich but distinct sub-fields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials—such as ReS$_2$ and ReSe$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, among others—have more intricate atomistic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials give rise to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as entirely new properties such as ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Novel electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations can also occur due to low symmetry. The "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic was assembled to highlight recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials.

Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups was investigated using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was found that in a mesogenic polymer, unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of the electric birefringence of a melt above the temperature of the nematic-isotropic phase transition can be described by a sum of several exponential processes, two of which play a decisive role. These primary processes replace each other in a temperature range of about fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also revealed two processes of orientational relaxation: the first is due to rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second is associated with motion of the main chain segments.

Deep hashing methods have demonstrated great retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits remains a key focus in deep hashing methods. A common strategy in these methods is to employ an activation function, e.g. $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, and minimize a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this approach may cause more hash bits to become trapped in the wrong saturated regions of the activation functions without escaping. We refer to this issue as the "dead bits problem (dbp)." Additionally, existing quantization loss can worsen dbp. In this paper, we propose a simple yet effective gradient amplifier applied before activation functions to mitigate dbp.

We study the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar whose existence is motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We examine both the possibility that the triplets are stable and contribute to the dark matter density, or that they decay via mixing with the Standard Model Higgs boson. The former is constrained by disappearing charged track searches at the LHC and by dark matter direct detection experiments, while the latter is limited by existing multilepton collider searches. We find that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is excluded by direct detection searches, while an unstable triplet with a mass below $230\ \mathrm{GeV}$ is ruled out at $95\%$ confidence level.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings observed around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than predicted in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario (sometimes referred to as "pericenter glow"). The standard scenario assumes an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis \(a\), whose eccentricity is raised to \(e_f\) after the gas disc has dispersed by secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width \(2ae_f\). In a slight modification of this scenario, narrower belts can form if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, which could arise from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. However, a primordial eccentricity might alternatively be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity, without requiring any planets.

An electron is typically considered to have only one type of kinetic energy, but could it possess more, due to its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is described well at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger-liquid (TLL) model, yet little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. Here, we report measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated wires using a tunneling spectroscopy technique. We observe two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, linked to spin and charge excitations, along with the emergence of three additional 1D 'replica' modes that intensify with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is adjusted by varying the amount of 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%.

$context$. The assembly history of the Milky Way is currently being unveiled thanks to the data provided by the $Gaia$ mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. $aims$. To constrain this formation path, we investigate the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the Milky Way has experienced. $methods$. To this end, we combined the kinematic information provided by $Gaia$ for nearly all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin we analyzed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. $results$. We find that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

The estimation of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a fundamental step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces **intrinsic**, an R package that implements novel state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset. Specifically, the methods included in this package are the two-NN, Gride, and HIDALGO models. To ensure these novel estimators are easily accessible, the package provides a few high-level, intuitive functions that rely on a broader set of efficient, low-level routines. **Intrinsic** encompasses models that fall into two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category includes the two-NN and Gride models. The functions dedicated to these two methods perform inference under both the frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. In the second category, we find HIDALGO, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrent behaviors on a nanosecond scale, promising to enable spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Here, two physical RC systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs) were proposed and modeled to process image classification tasks and nonlinear dynamic system predictions, respectively. Based on our micromagnetic simulation results of the nonlinear responses in MSM and STNO with current pulse stimulation, the handwritten digits recognition task demonstrates that an RC system using one single MSM achieves outstanding performance in image classification. Moreover, complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can also be effectively solved by a physical RC system composed of 24 STNOs, as confirmed in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms ranging from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we identify a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings: the fewer the items reporting a given signal, the larger the share of the overall traffic they collectively attract. This few-get-richer effect emerges in settings where there are few distinct categories of items (e.g., left-leaning news sources versus right-leaning news sources), and items are ranked based on their popularity. We demonstrate analytically that the few-get-richer effect arises when people tend to click on top-ranked items and have diverse preferences for the classes of items. Using simulations, we examine how the strength of the effect varies with assumptions about the setting and human behavior. We also test our predictions experimentally in an online study with human participants. Our findings have important implications for understanding the spread of misinformation.

Weight pruning has been widely acknowledged as a straightforward and effective method to eliminate redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), thereby achieving acceleration on various platforms. However, most pruning techniques are essentially trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, which lead to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To address this problem, we introduce a new sparsity dimension, namely pattern-based sparsity, which comprises pattern and connectivity sparsity, and achieves both high accuracy and hardware efficiency. With carefully designed patterns, the proposed pruning method consistently achieves accuracy improvement and enhanced feature extraction capability across various DNN architectures and datasets. Our pattern-aware pruning framework also enables pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning, and weight training simultaneously. Our approach to pattern-based sparsity naturally aligns with compiler optimization for highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs significantly from a treated group is vulnerable to bias from historical events that have different effects on the groups. Constructing a more closely matched control group by selecting a subset of the overall control group to align with the treated group may reduce bias. We examine this phenomenon in simulation studies. We analyze the effect of mountaintop removal mining (mrm) on mortality using a difference-in-differences approach that leverages the increase in mrm following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of mrm on mortality, we developed a more closely matched control group and obtained a 95% confidence interval that includes substantial adverse effects along with no effect and minor beneficial effects.

When constructing models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it is good practice to assess the models for their ability to reproduce the data. This can be done using visual predictive checks (VPC), which involve (1) multiple reproductions of the original study by simulation from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study, and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This procedure is a general method that is straightforward to apply. Here we examine the application of the method to time-to-event data and explore the special case when a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated after event time.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system through sequential schemes are presented. We discuss how similar protocols, relying both on repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can enable: (i) confining and protecting quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with Zeno physics. (ii) analytically predicting the probability that a quantum system is transferred into a target quantum state via stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstructing the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing in the frequency domain the filter functions driving the designed quantum sensor. The achievement of these tasks will enhance our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thus advancing quantum science and technologies.

Palms sweaty, heart racing, stomach in knots. You can't cry for help. Not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but it'd be so humiliating. No, you aren't being stalked by a monster, you're speaking in public, a fate some consider worse than death. See, when you're dead, you feel nothing; at a podium, you feel stage fright. But at some point we've all had to communicate in front of others, so you must try and overcome it. To start, understand what stage fright is. Humans, social animals that we are, are wired to worry about reputation. Public speaking can threaten it. Before a speech, you fret, 'What if people think I'm awful and I'm a fool?'

I can't think of anyone who just has one interest in life, and that's all they want to do forever. [The way we work], around 15 percent of American workers don't have traditional full-time jobs. They're part-time, contract workers, or temps. The term 'side hustle' perfectly fits this ethos where people combine multiple pursuits to make a living. The phrase 'side hustle' originated in popular African American newspapers. In the 1920s, these publications used 'hustle' to describe scams. By the 1950s, they also applied 'side hustle' to legitimate work. A side hustle differs slightly from a second job. A second job is often about necessity.

Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is made of thousands of steel parts, the other of a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One is imposed on the environment, the other shapes it. One is designed for nature, the other is designed by her. Michelangelo said that when he looked at raw marble, he saw a figure struggling to be free. The chisel was Michelangelo's only tool. But living things are not carved. They grow. And in our smallest units of life, our cells, we carry all the information needed for every other cell to function and to replicate. Tools also have consequences. At least since the industrial revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the demands of manufacturing and mass production.

Hello. My name is Simone. You know how people tell you if you get nervous onstage, picture the audience naked? Like it's this trick that's supposed to make you feel better. But I was thinking — imagining all of you naked in 2018 feels kind of weird and wrong. Like, we're working really hard on moving past stuff like that, so we need a new way to handle stage fright. And I realized that what I'd really like is to look at you as much as you're looking at me — just to even things out a little. So if I had way more eyeballs, then we'd all be really comfortable, right?

To do two things at once is to do neither." It's a great critique of multitasking, isn't it, often attributed to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus, although you know how these things are, he probably never said it. What I'm interested in, though, is — is it true? I mean, it's clearly true for emailing at the dinner table or texting while driving or possibly for live tweeting at a TED Talk, as well. But I'd like to argue that for an important kind of activity, doing two things at once — or three or even four — is precisely what we should be aiming for. Look no further than Albert Einstein. In 1905, he published four remarkable scientific papers.

I know this is going to sound strange, but I think robots can inspire us to be better humans. See, I grew up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, the home of Bethlehem Steel. My father was an engineer, and when I was growing up, he would teach me how things worked. We would build projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart that we built together. That's me behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. And one day, he came home, when I was about 10 years old, and at the dinner table, he announced that for our next project, we were going to build ... a robot.

Sustainability represents the what, the where, and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to understand how I impact them. I want to know how they impact me. I want to learn why they fish. I want to know how they rely on the water's bounty for their livelihood. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows us to celebrate the seafood that we're so fortunate to enjoy. So what do we call this? I think we call it restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.

The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel. The spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress. The stone-hearted miser haunted by the ghost of Christmas past. More than a century after his death, these remain iconic figures from the work of Charles Dickens. So striking is his body of work that it gave rise to its own adjective. But what are the qualities of Dickens's writing that make it so special? Dickens’s fiction brims with tension through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These elements of his work kept his audience eager for more. When first published, his stories were serialized, meaning they were released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals and only later reprinted as books.

Shah Rukh Khan: courage, determination, and a single-minded vision. These are the qualities the greatest achievers share. These are the brave hearts for whom failure is not an option. What seems to us an unconquerable sea, to our next speaker is an irresistible stage she was born to perform on. So let's dive straight into the story of our fearless speaker, Bhakti Sharma, who's making waves in the world of long-distance swimming. Bhakti Sharma. (Applause) Bhakti Sharma: imagine, in the scorching Rajasthan heat, on a sweltering summer afternoon, a two-and-a-half-year-old riding on a moped behind her mom, not knowing where they were headed. And 20 minutes later, that two-and-a-half-year-old finds herself completely submerged in water.

I'm going to talk about a technology that we're developing at Oxford now, which we believe will change the way computer games and Hollywood movies are made. That technology is simulating humans. It's simulated humans with a simulated body and a simulated nervous system to control that body. Now, before I discuss this technology further, let's take a quick look at how human characters currently appear in computer games. This is a clip from a game called *Grand Theft Auto 3.* We briefly saw this yesterday. And what you can see is—it's actually a very good game. It's one of the most successful games of all time.

Like a lot of people around the world, earlier this summer my friends and I were captivated by the Women's World Cup held in France. Here we are, watching these incredible athletes—the goals were spectacular, the games were clean and engaging, and at the same time, off the field, these women are advocating for equal pay, and in some countries, any pay at all for their sport. Because we were so engrossed, we wanted to watch the games live, and we decided that one of the Spanish-speaking networks in the US was the best place for us to start. And it wasn't until a few games into the tournament that a friend of mine asked me, "Why does it feel like everything I'm seeing is commercials for makeup and household cleaning products and diets?

I want to tell you about the future of money. Let's begin with a story about a culture that lived in Micronesia in the early 1900s, called the Yap. Now, I want to share this because their form of money is truly fascinating. They used these limestone discs called rai stones. However, the Yap didn’t actually move these rai stones around or exchange them the way we do with our coins, because rai stones can be quite massive. The largest is about four tons and 12 feet across. So the Yap simply kept track of who owned part of which stone. There's a tale about some sailors transporting a stone across the ocean when they encountered trouble and the stone sank into the sea.

You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. It’s impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist that you’re innocent anyway, you’ll likely be found guilty and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others for good measure, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession—or risk a public hanging? This was the dilemma facing those accused of witchcraft in the village of Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They were the victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misguided religious fervor—and a justice system that valued repentance over truth. Salem was settled in 1626 by Puritans, a group of English Protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of Salem. Conflicts with their Native American neighbors and groups of French settlers were commonplace.

There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to meet that demand. What if instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? That’s the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We’re not yet able to print complex organs, but simpler tissues including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange are already within our grasp. Bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3-D printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.

Good afternoon, I'm proud to be here at TEDxKrakow. I'll try to speak a little today about a phenomenon that can, and actually is changing the world, and whose name is people power. I'll begin with an anecdote, or for those of you who are Monty Python lovers, a Monty Python-type sketch. Here it is. It is December 15, 2010. Someone gives you a bet: you will look into a crystal ball, and you will see the future; the future will be accurate. But you must share it with the world. Okay, curiosity killed the cat, you take the bet, you look into the crystal ball. One hour later, you're sitting in a building of the national TV, on a top show, and you tell the story.

We're going to begin in 1964. Bob Dylan is 23 years old, and his career is just reaching its peak. He's been hailed the voice of a generation, and he's producing classic songs at a seemingly impossible rate, but there's a small group of dissenters, and they claim that Bob Dylan is stealing other people's songs. 2004. Brian Burton, aka Danger Mouse, takes The Beatles' *White Album*, combines it with Jay-Z's *The Black Album* to create *The Grey Album*. *The Grey Album* becomes an instant sensation online, and The Beatles' record company sends out numerous cease-and-desist letters for 'unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property.' Now, *The Grey Album* is a remix.

Well, that's kind of an obvious statement up there. I began with that sentence about 12 years ago, and I started in the context of developing countries, but you're sitting here from every corner of the world. So if you think of a map of your country, I believe you'll realize that for every country on earth, you could draw small circles to say, 'these are places where good teachers won't go.' On top of that, those are the places from where trouble arises. So we have an ironic problem — good teachers don't want to go to just those places where they're needed the most. I started in 1999 to try and address this issue with an experiment, which was a very simple experiment in New Delhi.

Currently, most refugees live in cities rather than in refugee camps. They represent over 60 percent of refugees globally. With the majority of refugees residing in urban areas, there is a strong need for a paradigm shift and new thinking. Rather than wasting money on building walls, it would be better to invest in programs that help refugees support themselves. (applause) We always have to leave behind all our possessions. But not our skills and knowledge. If given the opportunity to live productively, refugees can help themselves and contribute to their host country's development. I was born in the city of Bukavu, South Kivu, in the Democratic Republic of Congo. I am the fifth-born in a family of 12 children.

I have two questions for you. One: whose shoulders do you stand on? And two: what do you stand for? These are two questions that I always begin my poetry workshops with students because at times, poetry can seem like a distant art form for old white men who just appear as if they were born to be old, like, you know, Benjamin Button or something. And I ask my students these two questions, then I share how I answer them, which is in these three sentences: I am the daughter of Black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. And these are words I repeat in a mantra before every single poetry performance. In fact, I was doing it in the corner over there. I was making faces.

On October 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite, into space. This small metal sphere, less than two feet in diameter, ignited a space race between the U.S. and U.S.S.R. that would last for eighteen years and change the world as we know it. Sputnik was actually not the first piece of human technology to enter space. That distinction belongs to the V-2 rocket used by Germany in missile attacks against Allied cities as a last-ditch effort in the final years of World War II. It wasn't very effective, but, at the end of the war, both the U.S. and U.S.S.R. had seized the technology and the scientists who developed it, using them for their own projects.

I am a cultural omnivore, one whose daily commute is made possible by attachment to an iPod — an iPod that features Wagner and Mozart, pop diva Christina Aguilera, country singer Josh Turner, gangsta rap artist Kirk Franklin, concerti, symphonies and much more. I'm a voracious reader, one who enjoys Ian McEwan as well as Stephanie Meyer. I have read the Twilight tetralogy. And I live for my home theater, a home theater where I devour DVDs, video on demand and plenty of television. We are in a race against time, and we are losing. There is a rising tide of impatience, especially among young people, with global inaction. Your influence and ideas can help drive momentum for a carbon-neutral world by 2050. That is the only way to prevent the worst impacts of global heating. We have the tools, the science and the resources. Let us now enter this race with political will and energy.

Menstruation. A simple word describing a natural biological process, weighed down by centuries of stigma, has been transformed into something most of us can only discuss in whispers. But why? As I speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are experiencing a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, I can tell you that it's exhausting. It's exhausting to carefully pull out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuffing it into your pocket in the middle of a class and rushing to the washroom as discreetly as possible. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings pretending to be completely normal, while internally crying out from intense period cramps.

The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is located in the heart of the largest and most intact forest in the world, Canada's boreal forest. It spans across northern Canada, including Labrador, and is home to the largest remaining wild caribou herd on Earth: the George River caribou herd, numbering approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, when I visited, I couldn't spot any of them, but you have the antlers as proof. Throughout the boreal, we're blessed with this remarkable abundance of wetlands. Wetlands, globally, are among the most endangered ecosystems. They're vital ecosystems—they purify air, filter water, sequester vast amounts of greenhouse gases, and support a diverse array of species.

Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, made of fields, plains, and gardens. Four brothers wandered this celestial realm. They had no family other than each other—they didn’t even know their parents. One of the brothers, Deminan, looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had been cursed with this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit Yaya was out in his gardens, Deminan and his brothers sneaked into Yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to peer inside the gourd, they dropped it.

So, I had graduated seven years ago from Berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics, and I attended a career fair here on campus, where I'd gotten an interview with a start-up called Theranos. At the time, there wasn't much information about the company, but the little available was truly impressive. Essentially, the company was developing a medical device that could run your entire blood panel from a finger-stick of blood. This meant you wouldn't need a large needle in your arm to complete your blood test. The innovation was intriguing not only because it reduced pain, but also because it could potentially enable predictive diagnostics.

My journey to become a polar specialist, photographing and specializing in the polar regions, began when I was four years old, when my family moved from southern Canada to northern Baffin Island, near Greenland. There we lived with the Inuit in the tiny community of 200 people, where we were one of three non-Inuit families. In this community, we didn't have a television; we didn't have computers, obviously, or radio. We didn't even have a telephone. All of my time was spent outside with the Inuit, playing. The snow and the ice were my sandbox, and the Inuit were my teachers. And that's where I became truly obsessed with this polar realm.

In 1903, the president of the United States took a three-day camping trip in California’s Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt slept in a grove of towering sequoia trees, camped in a snowstorm, and spent hours talking around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist John Muir. Roosevelt famously loved the outdoors, but Muir had invited him there for more than just camping: Yosemite was in danger. Though Yosemite became protected land in 1864, the valley was still at risk of overdevelopment in 1903. It was at the heart of a decades-long struggle to set aside land for both preservation and public use—two goals that were much easier said than done. The battle over Yosemite began with the 1849 Gold Rush, when miners surged west, seeking gold in the Sierra Nevada foothills.

Hello. This is my first trip, the first time in life I'm outside the walls of Gaza. I'm so happy to be here. (applause) My dream always was to be a pilot, to fly a plane, to feel free in the sky, to touch the clouds. But that didn’t happen. Simply, I live in Gaza, where there is no airport. All borders are closed on every side. We live in one of the biggest prisons in the world. The only thing I can do is gaze at the sky. On some days, we are lucky if we have electricity for four or five hours. When it's cold, we make a fire outside or on the roof of our homes.

I am sorry I cannot show you my face, because if I do, the bad guys will come for me. My journey started 14 years ago. I was a young reporter. I had just graduated from college. Then I got a scoop. Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? That’s the question philosopher Robert Nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the Experience Machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that simulates real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch? You must permanently leave reality behind, but you'll hardly notice the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs will simply be replaced with an endless series of highs. Sounds great, right?

Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon operates in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other organisms die, much of their stored carbon returns to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon. But over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life turns into rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. And human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, also release some of that ancient carbon. Today, humans emit around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
